Another Pioneer

From DFW
Jump to: navigation, search

Back to David Foster Wallace or Oblivion: Stories.


Contents

  • 1 Summary
  • 2 Characters
  • 3 Themes/Motifs
  • 4 Voice
  • 5 Context
  • 6 Criticism

Summary

"Another Pioneer" is told (at least) fourth-hand, as a friend-of-friend-told-me type of story. The story being (re-)told is of a small jungle civilization's advancement and eventual downfall as it interacts with an exceptionally brilliant child/guru. The society is at first enthralled by the child's ability to help solve their problems, but as the demands for the growing child's intellect increase and the nature of the villager's questions become more complex, the villagers come to resent and fear the prodigy's abilities even as they grow more dependent on his wisdom. The prodigy eventually begins answering their questions with questions and challenging the most basic underlying assumptions of the civilization, which angers and confuses the villagers far more than (they believe) it helps them. The villagers grow angrier and more fearful, particularly after the child whispers something unknown to a fearless warrior and instantly drives him insane, and they eventually begin avoiding the child's platform in the center of the village altogether. Eventually, an enemy village dispatches a shaman to destroy the child, and he does so by asking the child to introspect and seriously think about the real possibility that the village will turn violently against its own prodigy. The people eventually do destroy the town and abandon it, leaving the now-metamorphized child behind in the burning village. The story is given several possible versions and several possible endings, much like a myth, as it is retold by someone who was himself told by someone who overheard it on a United flight, told by one passenger to another.

Characters

the brilliant child

the enemy village's shaman

the man on United flight, telling the story to a fellow passenger

the narrator

Other minor characters

Themes/Motifs

"Another Pioneer" is as much about the nature of storytelling as it is about its content. As already discussed above, the story is being retold from a retelling, and the many possible versions and ending embedded within the story make it myth-like, a permutation of Jorge Luis Borges's stories about recursivity and the imposition of consciousness on a narrative. Part of the story's point seems to be to demonstrate how each storyteller adds his own editorializations and commentaries, and how those commentaries often become inseparable from the content and plot of the story. Much like James Joyce does in Ulysses, Wallace is trying to demonstrate the relationship between style and substance in narrative. The highly self-conscious nature of "Another Pioneer"'s narrator is one example of the way in which a self-aware telling can highlight certain aspects of a tale, and in the process change its purpose. No doubt, with a less self-conscious, less philosophical narrator, the story would look much different: maybe simpler, maybe more complex.

Appropriately, the story itself is concerned with the effects of heightened self-consciousness on a society. "Another Pioneer" is in many ways a myth meant to demonstrate the repeated phrase of "The Suffering Channel": "Consciousness in Nature's Nightmare" (Oblivion: Stories 282). The brilliant child's knowledge and ability of reasoned inquiry begins as a boon to his village; but, as his inquiries begin to tear at the roots of their civilization, people realize the danger inherent in trying to survive without unquestionable moral/traditional standards. This danger is physicalized when the child drives a powerful warrior to insanity by merely whispering something in the warrior's ear.

If the child is read as a philosophical skeptic of sorts (and this reading is in many ways suitable), it becomes possible to read "Another Pioneer" as tying importantly back to Wallace's earlier fascination with and interpretation of Wittgenstein. Wittgenstein's On Certainty proposes that the proper functioning of a language (and, implicitly, a society) is dependent on the existence of something he called "hinge propositions." They are called hinge propositions because, like the hinges of a door, they must remain unchanging in order for the door (language) to function.) These hinge propositions are things that must be assumed in order order to talk or think or function. The child questions the existence and importance of hinge-like ideas as he questions the basic assumptions of his civilization.

It is thematically important, too, that the child is eventually abandoned and left to die by the very people he tried to enlighten.

Additionally, the story is filled with Jungian archetypes and plays on the fickle relationship between a people and progress.

Voice

The story is written as a single paragraph, as an unedited transcription of what is being told orally. The narrator is highly self-conscious and has a developed vocabulary, and he comments constantly on both the content of the story and the unreliability of his retelling. He has a distinct personality and set of verbal tics, and he gives the impression that he is telling the story to a group of wealthy colleagues or friends. It sounds much like 19th- and early-20th-century tale of adventure into strange lands. This is tied to the story's title: "Another Pioneer." The story beings: "Nevertheless gentlemen I fear the lone instance I can recall"....
